qas.question: What did the Vedanta school represent in Hindu philosophy?
On what aspects of Vedic did the Vedanta understanding focus?
On what did the Vedanta school lessen focus?
Due to differences in text interpretations,into  what did the Vedanta school separate?
What metaphysical concepts were included in the Vedanta school?
What represented the lack of knowledge-centered study?
During what era did knowledge-centered understanding emerge?
Who created the concepts of atman and Brahman?

context: <b5_0>The emergence of Vedanta school<b5_0/> represented a period when a more <a0_0>knowledge-centered understanding<a0_0/> began to emerge. These focussed on <a1_0><b6_0>jnana<b6_0/><a1_0/> (<b7_0>knowledge<b7_0/>) driven aspects of <b9_0>the Vedic religion<b9_0/> and the Upanishads. This included metaphysical concepts such as <a4_0>ātman and Brahman<a4_0/>, and emphasized meditation, self-discipline, self-knowledge and abstract spirituality, rather than <a2_0>ritualism<a2_0/>. The Upanishads were variously interpreted by <b8_0>ancient and medieval era<b8_0/> Vedanta scholars. Consequently, the Vedanta separated into <a3_0>many sub-schools<a3_0/>, ranging from theistic dualism to non-theistic monism, each interpreting the texts in its own way and producing its own series of sub-commentaries.
